items.title: VI Live: Wolves stevent af op eerste zege, Brighton op voorsprong
items.summary: In deze VI Live volgen we de hoogtepunten in verschillende competities. Met onder meer aandacht voor Celtic - Rangers FC, AFC Bournemouth - Arsenal en Espanyol - Barcelona.

items.title: Transfers PSV: bod Fulham op Pepi van tafel geveegd
items.summary: Ook buiten de transferperiode om volgt VI het transfernieuws bij PSV op de voet, ook omdat het sneller dan je denkt alweer januari is. De doelwitten van de Eindhovenaren, duiding van de clubwatcher, of aandacht in buitenlandse media. We verzamelen alles hier.

items.title: PSV laat Pepi niet gaan ondanks Fulham-bod, Nagalo mag weg
items.summary: PSV heeft in de afgelopen periode een bod van Fulham op Ricardo Pepi afgeslagen en is niet van plan om de Amerikaanse spits deze winter van de hand te doen. In Eindhoven wordt op dit moment een rustige winter verwacht waarin wel verdediger Adamo Nagalo verkocht mag worden.

items.title: Wolves v West Ham, Brighton v Burnley, and more: football clockwatch ‚Äì live
items.summary: ‚öΩ Get updates from England, Scotland and further afield ‚öΩ Live scores | Tables | Follow us on Bluesky | Email Billy A bit more on Pablo Felipe, West Ham‚Äôs new signing. Position: Striker Age: 22 Nationality: Brazil Signed from: Gil Vicente (Portugal) This season: 14 games, 10 goals Form (last 6 games): 6 goals, 1 assist The intensity levels are better. There‚Äôs more of a confidence and belief but that‚Äôs only going to come from more results and more performances and being more consistent with what we do. There are certainly certain things that we‚Äôve improved on, but it‚Äôs a difficult league, and we came in at a difficult moment, so it was always going to be hard to instantly get those results. I said to the lads after the [United] game that we need to get that performance level at home. That‚Äôs the most important thing for us now. Continue reading...

items.title: 'We are together with the board' - Nancy defiant after Celtic loss
items.summary: Celtic manager Wilfried Nancy insists he is still "together with the board" and believes "we can turn things around" despite falling to a sixth loss in eight games following the derby defeat to Rangers.

items.title: Sources: Rosenior frontrunner to replace Maresca
items.summary: Strasbourg boss Liam Rosenior is the leading candidate to succeed Enzo Maresca as Chelsea head coach, sources have told ESPN.

items.title: Alonso unsure when Mbappe (knee) will return
items.summary: Xabi Alonso has admitted he "doesn't know" when Kylian Mbapp√© will return for Real Madrid, saying the club are working to have the star forward back from injury "as soon as possible."

items.title: Pep denies Maresca, City links: 'I have a contract'
items.summary: Pep Guardiola has reiterated his desire to stay on at Manchester City amid fresh rumours surrounding Enzo Maresca.

items.title: Farioli veegt speculaties over snel vertrek naar Chelsea van tafel
items.summary: Voor Francesco Farioli is het geen optie om FC Porto gedurende dit seizoen te verlaten voor een stap hogerop. Dat heeft de Italiaanse coach tijdens een persmoment heel duidelijk gemaakt, nadat hij gelinkt werd aan Chelsea.

items.title: John McGinn double sinks Forest and provides perfect tonic for Aston Villa
items.summary: Aston Villa continue to surpass expectations as they bounced back from defeat by Arsenal to cement their place in the top three. Ollie Watkins celebrated his 250th appearance for the club with his fourth goal in three games and John McGinn added two more as Unai Emery‚Äôs side won their 11th straight home game. Villa‚Äôs ability to score out of next to nothing epitomises their season. They managed this game superbly, inflicting a fourth straight defeat on Nottingham Forest, but if the league table was made up of their expected goals difference, they would have started this weekend in 15th place. Continue reading...

items.title: Nancy plunged into deeper Celtic crisis after Chermiti leads Rangers in derby
items.summary: Wilfried Nancy spent a memorable Friday press conference pleading for time, context and understanding as he visibly struggles with the role of Celtic manager. This outcome ‚Äì and the nature of it ‚Äì will do nothing for Nancy‚Äôs hopes of keeping his job. Celtic‚Äôs beleaguered directors now face a critical and imminent decision over whether to keep faith with the Frenchman or write his appointment off as a bad mistake. This marked a sixth defeat in eight games for Nancy. It arrived against the backdrop of revolt from paying customers. Celtic feel an on- and off-field mess. Nancy is on the precipice. Continue reading...

items.title: Paul loses WBA cruiserweight ranking after defeat to Joshua
items.summary: Jake Paul has slipped out of the WBA cruiserweight rankings after losing his heavyweight clash with Anthony Joshua in Miami last month.

items.title: Liverpool latest: We have no chance of retaining title, says MacAllister

items.summary: Iga Swiatek says women's tennis does not need the 'Battle of the Sexes' and is able to "stand on its own".

items.title: Blackburn to Barcelona - Dolan's 'unbelievable' journey to Espanyol
items.summary: Five years ago, Tyrhys Dolan was playing for Clitheroe - now he is preparing to face Barcelona in the Catalan derby.

items.title: I‚Äôm the ‚Äòmiracle‚Äô woken from a coma by Kenny Dalglish after Hillsborough. And now I‚Äôve met him again
items.summary: It‚Äôs said that you should never meet your heroes, but 36 years after the Liverpool manager sat by my hospital bed, I got to thank our greatest ally Born to a son of Anfield in a Warwickshire village, I grew up geographically remote from my spiritual football home. Emotionally, though, the pull of the boys in red was ever-present: from my first game at Anfield in 1974 to FA Cup final defeat at Wembley in ‚Äô77, to witnessing the first of Liverpool‚Äôs six European Cups, in Rome, when my first hero, Kevin Keegan, ran Berti Vogts ragged. I cried when Keegan left, but soon a new king was born in my imagination: Kenny Dalglish, that wily, tough, insanely skilful Scot. I travelled the country to follow my team through the peaks and troughs that culminated in the lowest possible low, on 15 April 1989, the day of the FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest. There are many things I remember about Hillsborough, some of which returned to me years, even decades, later. My dad saying: ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs a nice day tomorrow, we‚Äôll go.‚Äù Ian St John on the end of my hospital bed. My best mate laughing as I struggled to eat a yoghurt. The endless bright white lights of the Royal Hallamshire. The surreal trip to my local hospital in an ancient, drafty ambulance. One thing I don‚Äôt remember, though, is meeting my hero. And for good reason. For I‚Äôm the ‚Äúmiracle‚Äù boy woken by the sound of Kenny‚Äôs voice when he spoke at my bedside. Continue reading...
